title: Introduction to Film Studies
overview: Introduction to fundamental film terminology, history, and concepts, providing a foundation for further studies
description: This module introduces students to the essential aspects of film studies, covering basic terminology, historical developments, and key concepts in the field. Students will learn about the evolution of cinema, significant movements, and influential films. The course aims to build a solid groundwork for analysing and appreciating films in more advanced modules.
aims: Provide foundational knowledge of film history and concepts.
Equip students with basic analytical skills for film study.
Prepare students for advanced film analysis in later modules.
recommendedReading: Film Art: An Introduction by David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson

title: Film Theory
overview: Examination of major theoretical frameworks in film, including formalism, realism, and auteur theory.
description: This module delves into significant theoretical perspectives that have shaped film studies, such as formalism, realism, and auteur theory. Students will explore how these theories apply to the analysis of films and filmmakers. The course includes critical discussions and comparative analyses to deepen understanding of film as an art form.
aims: Understand and critically engage with major film theories.
Apply theoretical frameworks to film analysis.
Enhance critical thinking and analytical skills.
recommendedReading: Film Theory and Criticism edited by Leo Braudy and Marshall Cohen

title: Film Production Fundamentals
overview: Introduction to practical aspects of filmmaking, including camera operation, lighting, sound, and editing.
description: This hands-on module introduces students to the fundamental techniques of film production. Covering essential skills such as camera operation, lighting, sound recording, and editing, it provides practical experience and technical knowledge necessary for creating short films. Students will engage in practical projects to apply their learning.
aims: Develop basic practical skills in filmmaking.
Understand technical aspects of film production.
Prepare for more advanced production work in future modules.
recommendedReading: In the Blink of an Eye by Walter Murch

title: World Cinema
overview: Exploration of non-mainstream films from various cultures, fostering an appreciation for global cinematic diversity.
description: This module examines the diversity of world cinema, focusing on films and movements outside the mainstream Western canon. Students will study influential filmmakers, genres, and cinematic traditions from different cultures, gaining a broader perspective on global cinema. The course emphasises the cultural, social, and political contexts of these films.
aims: Foster appreciation for global cinematic diversity.
Understand cultural and historical contexts of world cinema.
Develop research skills through exploration of global film movements.
recommendedReading: Global Art Cinema: New Theories and Histories by Rosalind Galt and Karl Schoonover

title: Screenwriting Fundamentals
overview: Essentials of screenwriting, including formatting, dialogue, and story structure.
description: This module focuses on the basics of screenwriting, covering the essential elements of crafting a screenplay. Students will learn about story structure, character development, dialogue writing, and screenplay formatting. The course aims to provide the skills needed to create compelling and professional-quality scripts.
aims: Develop skills in crafting compelling screenplays.
Understand the principles of story structure and character development.
Learn the technical aspects of screenplay formatting.
recommendedReading: The Anatomy of Story by John Truby

title: Visual Effects & Cinematography
overview: Exploration of visual effects and camera techniques in filmmaking.
description: This module introduces students to the visual elements of filmmaking, focusing on cinematography and visual effects. Students will learn about different camera techniques, shot compositions, and the use of visual effects to enhance storytelling. The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical exercises.
aims: Understand the visual elements of filmmaking.
Develop skills in camera techniques and visual effects.
Apply theoretical knowledge in practical projects.
recommendedReading: Cinematography: Theory and Practice by Blain Brown

title: History of Television
overview: Examination of the evolution of television as a medium and its cultural impact.
description: This module explores the history of television, tracing its development from its inception to the present day. Students will study key moments in television history, influential TV shows, and the medium's impact on culture and society. The course encourages critical analysis of television as a cultural and artistic form.
aims: Understand the evolution of television as a medium.
Analyse the cultural and societal impact of television.
Develop research and critical analysis skills.
recommendedReading: Television: Critical Methods and Applications edited by Jeremy G. Butler

title: Sound Design for Film
overview: Exploration of the role of sound design and music in enhancing cinematic storytelling.
description: This module examines the critical role of sound design and film scoring in cinema. Students will learn about the technical and creative aspects of sound in film, including how sound effects, dialogue, and music contribute to the storytelling process. Practical exercises will help students develop skills in creating effective soundscapes for film.
aims: Develop an understanding of how sound and music enhance cinematic storytelling.
Learn technical and creative aspects of sound design and film scoring.
Apply sound design techniques in practical projects.
recommendedReading: The Sound of Cinema: Hollywood Film Music from the Silents to the Present by Sean Wilson
